titlestmt.titleproper: Inventory of the Helen Praeger Young Interviews
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Hoover Institution Archives Staff.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-05-22T11:52-0700
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

did.abstract: Sound recordings and translations of transcripts of interviews of women veterans of the Chinese Long March of 1934-1935. Used as research material for the book by Helen Praeger Young, Choosing Revolution: Chinese Women Soldiers on the Long March (Urbana, 2001).

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Helen Praeger Young interviews, [Box number], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 2008.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection mainly contains sound recordings and translations of transcripts of interviews of women veterans of the Chinese Long March of 1934-1935 used as research material for the book by Helen Praeger Young, Choosing Revolution: Chinese Women Soldiers on the Long March (Urbana, 2001). Additionally, the collection contains research material in both English and Chinese, such as biographical material about the women interviewed, the Long March, maps of China, caligraphy samples, and other printed material and drafts of various editions of the book with comments from editors and peers at the "Stanford Biographers Seminar."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On compact sound cassettes. Titles taken directly from labels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains transcripts of interviews, biographical notes on subjects, and drafts of chapters incorporating interviews with maps and scanned photos included.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Chen Zongying joins the Long March in August 1934 in the Sixth Army Group.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Deng Liujin was a First Front Army veteran.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: He Manqiu was a Fourth Front Army veteran.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Jian Xianren was a Second Front Army veteran.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Kang Keqing was the wife of the commander-in-chief of the army, Marshal Zhu De. Keqing was transferred from the First Front Army to the Fourth Front Army in June 1935.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Lin Yueqin was a Fourth Front Army veteran, joined the Long March in 1932.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Ma Yixiang was a Second Front Army veteran; she joined the army at age 11.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Quan Weihua was a Fourth Front Army veteran.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Wang Dingguo was a Fourth Front Army veteran.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Wang Quanyuan was transferred from the First Front Army to the Fourth Front Army in June 1935. In 1936, Quanyuan commanded a regiment of women.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Zhang Wen was a Fourth Front Army veteran.

did.unittitle: Men's interviews and mixed materials regarding Chinese Communist Forces,
Maps and printed material on China and the Long March,
Drafts, "Women's Voices on the Long March" and "Women Soldiers of the Long March,"
Research material, and drafts with notes from "Biographers Seminar,"
Preliminary list of maps by chapter,
Articles on women and oral history,
Long March Images, scanned pictures and photographs,
Chinese source material on the Long March, Chinese women,
Thesis: "Women and the Chinese Communist Party,"
"Wang Yizhi: A Woman in Revolution," Gilmartin and Stranahan,
Papers and articles on women's issues, women in politics,
University of Illinois Urbana Press "Choosing Revolution" proposal and draft,
Publications and drafts, on women and war,
"Women's Voices on the Long March" notes and chapter drafts,
"Will to Survive," "Choosing Revolution" drafts and proposals,
"Women on the Long March," "Women's Voices" chapter drafts,
Printed material on Chinese communist party, politics,
Writings, drafts regarding the organization of the Long March,
Dijkstra/Dykstra Literary Agency material and correspondence,
"The Rise of the Chinese Communist Party,"
